qas.question: In 1996, multiple groups filed lawsuits to hold Shell accountable for what?

answers.text: alleged human rights violations in Nigeria

qas.question: Shell was accused of participating in the execution of which southern Nigerian tribal leader?
In what year did Shell agree to settle the lawsuits filed in 1996?
For what amount did Shell agree to settle the 1996 lawsuits?
In contrast to its agreement to settle the 1996 lawsuits, Shell refused to do what?

answers.text: accepted any liability over the allegations against it

qas.question: Brian Anderson was the leader of what tribe?
What was Ken Saro-Wiwa accused of?
How much did Shell pay to the Ogoni tribe?

context: In the beginning of <b9_0>1996<b9_0/>, several human rights groups brought cases to hold Shell accountable for <a0_0>alleged <b7_0>human rights violations<b7_0/> in Nigeria<a0_0/>, including summary execution, crimes against humanity, torture, inhumane treatment and arbitrary arrest and detention. In particular, Shell stood accused of collaborating in the execution of <a1_0>Ken Saro-Wiwa<a1_0/> and eight other leaders of the <b6_0>Ogoni<b6_0/> tribe of southern Nigeria, who were hanged in <b5_0>1995<b5_0/> by Nigeria's then military rulers. The lawsuits were brought against Royal Dutch Shell and Brian Anderson, the head of its Nigerian operation. In <a2_0>2009<a2_0/>, Shell agreed to pay <a3_0><b8_0>$15.5m<b8_0/><a3_0/> in a legal settlement. Shell has not <a4_0>accepted any liability over the allegations against it<a4_0/>.
